title: CTRL0000083782 - Transcribed Interview of Rachel Craddock, (May 24, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 2:06 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
We will go on the record.
This is a transcribed interview conducted by the House Select
Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the U.S. Capitol, pursuant to House
Ms. Craddock, could you please state and spell your full name for the record?
My name is Rachel Craddock, R-a-c-h-e-1, last name
This will be a staff-led interview.
the staff for the select committee.
But as of now, they're not with us.
But I do have with me an
And I introduced myself before, but I'll say it
I'm the Senior Investigative Counsel on
At this time I know you have Mr. Benson with you, but I'd ask him to please
Members of the select committee may choose
announce himself and spell his name for the record.
Daniel Benson, B-e-n-s-o-n, of Kasowitz Benson with the
Before we start, I'll go over just a few ground rules to make this go smoothly
reporter who's on who will record what're saying today and transcribe it.
And the first is just to let you know, you've already seen, is we have an official
So for the clarity of the record, I just ask that you wait until I or whoever else asks
the question finishes before you answer, and we'll wait for you to finish your answer
before we ask our next question.
The other point that I'll make, having -- you having nodded your head, is that the
reporter cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking or nodding your head.
if at any point in response you do that, excuse me in advance, but we'll ask you to say yes
Now all we're asking today is that you provide the best answer you can based on
your recollection of the events we'll talk about.
a question that's not clear, just let us know.
If I ask a question or someone else asks
And we'll do our best to rephrase it so that
And if you don't know the answer or you don't remember, just say so.
If at any point you need a break, whether for comfort or to talk to Mr. Benson
Just let know and we'll go on mute and can turn
the cameras to off and just let us know when you're ready to come back.
Now, throughout the interview, I may show you an exhibit.
And if I do, we'll just
flash it up on the screen.
I sent them to Mr. Benson in advance yesterday.
you've had a chance to look at them, that's great.
to look at them, if they're on the screen, take whatever time you need to familiarize
yourself with them before you answer a question.
Even if you did, if you need more time
Also, I want to remind you, as we do any witness who meets with the select
committee, that it is unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress, and
that to do so could result in criminal penalties.
So are you -- do you understand all of
Do you have any questions before we get started?
When you leaned in just then, the audio was much
I think, as you answer, it will be helpful if you do lean a little bit closer.
Now I do see that Mrs. Murphy, who's a member of the select committee, is
And I'll ask if the clerk or the staff monitor can let her in.
So for the record, Mrs. Murphy has joined us.
Thank you for being here today.
Ms. Craddock, as we get started, I just want to reflect for the record
that you're appearing here today voluntarily without the need for a subpoena.
So I reached out to you.
And then you let me know that you were
retaining an attorney, and then Mr. Benson reached out to me.
And what is your highest level of education?
I have a bachelors in science.
My current occupation is an operations director for Affinity Partners.
Is it correct that you worked for lvanka Trump during her time in the White
What year and month, to the best you can remember, did you start working
The exact month, I don't remember.
Prior to that, taking that role, where were you working?
I was also at the White House.
Who were you reporting to in the press office?
Now as of January 2021, when you left the White House, what was your job
I was in the press office.
I think the audio cut out.
And what generally were your responsibilities?
Special Assistant to the President was my job title.
were mainly focused on operations, logistics, and touched on a few policy areas.
Operations and logistics with respect to what Ms. Trump was working on, or
did you have a broader portfolio?
And what were generally the policy prerogatives that you were working on
toward the end of 2020 and January of 2021?
I worked on a lot of the COVID-19 relief efforts, such as the Farmers to
Did you stay at the White House through the last day of President Trump's
Now where was your office space located on the White House grounds?
In the West Wing on the second floor.
There's a little cove that was next to
That answered my next question where her office was in relation to yours.
But within the office space that you had, did you have a TV?
Did Ms. Trump within her office space have a TV or TVs in the plural?
If you could, just situate us, because it might be relevant later.
walked into Ms. Trump's office, what was the layout as someone walking into it where,
you know, the TV was, where her desk was or wherever she would sit?
So when you walk in, it's two -- kind of a two-part office.
There was a conference table right when you walked in that sat about, I guess, eight to 10
And then you go to the -- you look to the left, and then there was a chair.
then there was, like, a separate -- a wall separation.
also on the left side of the room was where her computer/standing desk was.
And that's where the TV was, kind
And there was a couch in front of the TV.
And then back in the corner
So the -- in terms of your support for Ms. Trump, was there anyone else
I'm just focusing on the time of November 2020 to the end of
We had -- would you like me to list out everybody?
I don't know if it's just handful of people.
We were a small, agile office.
So the Chief of Staff was Julie Radford.
then the policy team was Rosemary Lahasky and Stewart Young.
Kelly and Kathryn Walker and then myself.
I believe it was Ms. Mahasky, you said?
Because that's the only the name that might not a
have a common spelling, if you know.
Did any of the people you just discussed share office space with Ms. Trump
within her office, or were they all situated outside somewhere within the White House
They were situated, besides Kathryn, were all situate -- actually, have a lot of
So in November through January, Rosemary Lahasky, Julie Radford, myself,
and Kathryn Walker were positioned on the second floor of the West Wing.
Young and Lynn Kelly were across the street in the executive -- EEOB is what we called it.
So I'll stop there to see if anybody has any questions just on Ms. Craddock's
And I don't see that anyone does.
So I'm just going to go and talk and ask a few questions about the presidential
And all the questions I'll ask are just to the best of your knowledge.
to your knowledge, what, if any, involvement did Ms. Trump have in the efforts of
President Trump and those working on his behalf to challenge the results of the election?
To the best of my knowledge, no participation.
Did Ms. Trump share with you her views about the efforts made by President
Trump and those working on his behalf to challenge the election results?
Did Ms. Trump ever express to you or share with you the view that she
Or that the election was a fraud?
Did Ms. Trump ever express to you that she believed President Trump had
Or that he should, that is, President Trump, concede the election to Joe
Did Ms. Trump ever recount to you or share with you discussions that she
had with President Trump about whether he won or lost the election?
Did anyone else ever recount to you discussions that they had personally
with President Trump about whether he won or lost the election?
To the best of my knowledge, no.
Now prior to January 6th of 2021, were you privy to any discussion among
White House staff, Ms. Trump included, about Vice President Pence's role on January 6th
with respect to the certification of the vote?
No, I was not privy, nor did I hear anything.
Now as -- the time we're talking about was within the pandemic, I know we
But particularly back then, was your day-to-day in that timeframe, were you
coming to work as a general matter?
And was Ms. Trump also coming to work every day as a general matter?
So now, turning to the rally at the Ellipse on January 6th, are you familiar
generally with the fact that the rally occurred and President Trump spoke there?
Do you recall how you first learned that President Trump would be speaking
I believe it was a day or two before.
And how did you learn about it?
Secret Service actually told me that there was an event, and I did not know
Did you have any discussions with Ms. Trump about the event before it took
So were you aware of whether she was considering whether to speak at the
I was not aware of those -- I wasn't a part of any of the discussions.
Similarly, were you a part of any discussions about who else would be
speaking at the event other than possibly Ms. Trump and the President?
I did not, or I was not.
Prior to the event that is on January 6th or the day of, were you privy to any
discussions among White House staff, Ms. Trump included, about the potential for
Now on the day of January 6th itself, were you at work that day?
Do you remember about what time you got to work?
Between 9:00 and 10:00 a.m., a little later than normal.
Any reason you can remember about why you were running later that day?
Just with it being an event, it's a little bit harder, traffic-wise, to get in.
Do you recall what, if anything, was on your schedule for the day?
with respect to Ms. Trump, did she have meetings or any events that she was scheduled
I don't remember the exact meetings, but we did have items on the
I printed off a schedule card that morning.
Prior to that day, were you and your colleagues supporting Ms. Trump
involved in the transition effort between the Trump and the Biden administration?
And when you say "actively," what does that mean?
That day, we were working on memos.
We were meeting with her about
the transition memos and, you know, preparing for that transition.
Is it fair to say -- I didn't mean to cut you off.
It was a lot of work.
So fair to say, as of January 6th, your expectation was that President Trump's
administration would end on January 20th and Joe Biden would be sworn in as president?
And how long had you been working actively on the transition effort?
Now, you know, we know from various documents and testimony that
Ms. Trump was with President Trump the morning of January 6th, first in the residence,
and then in the Oval Office with other members of her family.
generally that day that she was with her family and the President --
Did you see her before she joined her family and her father?
And we're also aware generally that, while in the Oval Office, President
Trump called Vice President Pence that morning of the 6th to discuss the upcoming
certification of the election results in Congress, and that Ms. Trump was there in the Oval
Office when that call took place.
Whether on January 6th or after, so through today, did
Ms. Trump ever recount with you the events of the morning of January 6th, what she
observed, being there with her father and her other family members?
All she said was that it was a very intense call.
The call between the President and Vice President Pence?
And when do you remember her telling you about that call?
In the car on the way to the Ellipse.
Did anybody else go with the two of you from Ms. Trump's staff?
And had it been your plan for you personally to attend the Ellipse rally
So I'll -- so you went to the Ellipse yourself with Ms. Trump?
Her Chief of Staff, Julie Radford.
You knew you were going to go?
So why is it that you ended up going with her to the event?
Just being the assistant and doing a lot of the operations and logistics, I
coordinated those fairly last minute with Secret Service, and ended up just jumping in to
You said you saw Ms. Trump before she went to see -- to meet with her
And at that point did you already know you'd be going to the Ellipse rally
Did she tell you in advance of meeting with her father and family that
morning what she expected to happen that day?
And did you know whether or not she would be speaking at the event?
I knew she was not speaking.
Did she tell you why she was not speaking?
Do you remember during -- how is it that you -- just trying to go through how
you made your way to the Ellipse.
How did you know it was time to leave?
I had emailed that morning, asking where they were leaving from, what time
everyone, because I didn't have any details.
And that's when the decision to go was made.
Do you remember who that was?
So, for instance, we know that Jared
Small was, I believe, working on the event and also Max Miller.
I think -- well, it was the person who did, like, the -- I think it was Ryan
And we know that, at least as compared to the schedule for the day's events,
President Trump ran behind in terms of getting to the Ellipse.
was a later arrival than was planned?
I didn't know the schedule, so no.
So then who told to you come down to get in the car, if you
I came down to the car early and sat in the car.
And Ms. Radford was with you as well?
So you sat in the car until Ms. Trump joined to you drive over to the Ellipse?
When Ms. Trump got in the car with you, did anybody else join her?
For how long, I don't know.
And what, as best you can remember, what did she discuss with the two of
you in the car when she joined you?
The only thing that was said, to my knowledge, was that there was a very
intense call between the President and the Vice President.
What did Ms. Trump's mood appear to be like at that time as she was
Did you understand the call to have been about the joint session?
at least say that much, it was about what Vice President Pence was going to do that day?
No, she didn't go into any detail.
Did you or Ms. Radford ask her for more details about the call?
So a fairly quick trip to get to the Ellipse, I imagine, from the White House?
When you got to the Ellipse, can you just walk us through what you did
between the time you got there and when President Trump took the stage?
We walked in, and they had white, tent-like structures set up.
and then, at some point, he took the stage.
less crowded tent to be at.
They had TVs in the back of that area.
We were back there pretty briefly,
And then we went to go find a warmer tent,
Before President Trump took the stage, at any point that morning, had you
heard any discussion about President Trump's desire to go to the Capitol after he was
Now were you able to hear the President's speech from wherever you were,
getting warm, or in the tent that morning?
Were you following it closely and listening to everything he was saying?
Did you hear, while the President was speaking, him say words to the effect
that he was going to go to the Capitol with the people who were there at the rally after
Have you since heard the fact that he said that during the speech?
Did you stay at the Ellipse through the end of President Trump's speech?
And Ms. Trump stayed there as well?
So after the President was done speaking, what happened next?
We briskly walked to the motorcade.
So the three of you got back in the car together?
Did you have any interaction with President Trump or hear him interacting
with others before you got back in the motorcade?
So from -- within the -- between the time you were at the Ellipse and getting
We were in the cars before.
back in the car, did you have any further conversation with Ms. Trump or hear her talk
with others about the phone call between President Trump and Vice President Pence
Did you hear the President during his remarks talk about Vice President
Pence and his needs to have courage and to do the right thing during the joint session, in
When you got -- what did you do when you got back to the White House?
I went straight to the Navy Mess to pick up lunch.
For the whole -- the whole group.
After you picked up lunch, where did you go?
Straight back up to the office.
Approximately what time do you remember this being at?
Did Ms. Trump come with you?
have records that show that President Trump arrived back at the White House roughly at,
Actually, no, because I know I was trying to rush to -- I remember trying to
rush to place the Navy Mess order and the Navy Mess closes at 2:00 p.m.
Does that sound about when you would have gotten back?
In the motorcade, would President have gone first?
Do you mean to get into the vehicles?
Or rather to travel in the vehicles, once you're in them and the vehicles
His car's at the beginning of the motorcade.
So just before 2:00 o'clock is when the Navy Mess closes.
order in, in time to get the food?
Yeah, a couple of minutes to spare.
At any time before you put the order in for food, did you become aware of
violence or a disturbance at the Capitol?
When did you first become aware, as best you can remember?
Not until after we ate lunch.
Which would have been around what time, if you can remember?
Sometime in the 2:00, probably the 2:00 to 2:30 window, just based on
when I probably picked up the food.
Did you eat together with Ms. Trump and others on her staff?
So you delivered the food to everybody, and then you went back to your
And delivered food to Ms. Trump as well?
And at the time that you delivered food, do you remember whether or not
the TV was on in her office?
As a general matter, would she have the TV on, on any given day when she
So how is it that you came to learn about the violence?
Her Chief of Staff had gone in, I mean, as she normally did, Julie Radford,
because we were working on, like, transition documents at that point.
gone in, and the door was cracked.
know what they were seeing in the room, but I knew Julie had, at one point, seen
And I could hear Julie say something.
So the TV was on, and I heard the volume
And that's all I really remember.
But that stands out in your mind because you knew at the time that
Ms. Radford was telling Ms. Trump about something was wrong at the Capitol?
Something -- when I heard the TV volume go up, I
could just, having worked for them for 2 years, I could just tell something was wrong.
But this -- what you're describing is in response to my question
about how you learned that there was a disturbance or violence at the Capitol.
between the time you hear Ms. Radford go into Ms. Trump's office and the volume on the
TV go up, how is it that you then come to know that something is actually wrong at the
We started talking about social media.
something out and they asked for my input.
learned more about it, what was going on.
There was -- she wanted to put
And that's when I went into the room and
When you say she wanted to put something out and wanted your input,
Did she come out and get you, or did Ms. Radford come out and get you?
So you sat close enough you heard your name and you went in.
you went in, was the TV on and you could see the coverage of what was happening at the
And so what message did Ms. Trump at that time say she wanted to put out,
What did she want to say?
You know, peaceful protesting is okay, but violence is never the answer.
mean, to the best of my knowledge, that's what I remember.
And what was the general -- the mood of the office at that point, seeing
what you were seeing on the TV and what was developing?
I mean, we were pretty upset.
Was anyone else there in the office with you and Ms. Radford and
Ms. Trump at the time you're discussing this?
So what happened from that point forward?
At some point, she went downstairs, and Julie and I stayed upstairs.
So Ms. Trump, that is, went downstairs?
Did she tell you why she was going downstairs?
How soon after you went in the office did she leave to go downstairs?
Was it a matter of minutes, a half an hour, an hour?
Did you have a sense of where she was going, that is, to go -- whether to see
her father or to go see other White House officials?
My understanding, it was to the Oval.
And had anybody asked her to come down to the Oval, to your knowledge,
How long was Ms. Trump gone until you saw her again?
Had you-all -- had someone put out a statement on social media on
It was agreed upon before she left, and it was put out right as she was gone.
Right as she was gone, in other words --
Who posted it then to social media?
Having seen her Twitter, is this the tweet that mentioned American
Now this was at roughly 3:15 in the afternoon, after her father had tweeted.
you remember that it was close in time to a tweet by President Trump?
I was only focused on hers.
And to your knowledge, when you went into the office, when you were
asked to come in, was that when Ms. Trump was first learning about the violence at the
Capitol from what you could observe?
From what I could observe, I think so, yeah.
And you had come straight from the Navy Mess after getting the lunch up to
your office and had stayed there?
But you had come up from the Navy Mess to your office, delivered
lunch, and stayed at your desk until you were called in to help with the tweet?
To the best of my knowledge, that's what I remember.
Did you see anybody else go in or out of Ms. Trump's office other than
That was before or after Ms. Radford went in the office and the TV volume
Not at this exact moment, but there were people, one person in particular,
And what do you remember about that with Mr. Herschmann coming in?
So obviously, by this point -- not obviously -- had Ms. Trump come back
upstairs from wherever she had been in the Oval Office?
Why don't I start with this?
What do you remember about your
interactions with Ms. Trump when you saw her next, after she had left to go to the Oval
And what did she tell you at that time?
Did you ever ask her what was going on with the President and what was
being done to address the violence at the Capitol?
Did she, at any point that day, tell you about her discussions with her father
about what was going on at the Capitol?
Did she tell you about her discussions with anyone else within the White
House, whether Mark Meadows, Dan Scavino, you know, Pat Cipollone, anybody?
Did you hear her talking with other people about the violence at the Capitol?
It's been reported, and we've gathered evidence that Ms. Trump met with
her father in the private dining room off the Oval Office, and at least had input into one of
the tweets he sent out that day.
Did she ever talk to you about that, about giving input to her father about what to
say in his tweets about the violence?
Were you following or aware of what the President was tweeting that day on
But at some point that day you were aware of the things he'd been saying?
And were you aware, as the attack was ongoing at the Capitol, that various
people were saying that the President should, you know, make a statement or do a video
address of some sort to tell people to go home?
Did you ask if I was aware of that?
What, if any, discussions did you hear within the White House during this
time about if the President was going to make such an address, and if he was, what he
I was not privy to any of those conversations.
Are you aware that eventually at 4:17 p.m. he did send out a tweet with a
video, telling people to go home?
I saw the video on Twitter.
To your knowledge or, rather, did you speak to anybody within the White
House who was involved in the filming of that video, or drafting the remarks for the
To your knowledge, did Ms. Trump have anything to do with that video?
Now going back to Mr. Herschmann coming up to Ms. Trump's office, again,
as best you can remember, what happened when he came up?
I was not in the room.
Do you remember for how long -- oh, you said you left the office.
It's -- I guess I should say it's a very small space.
When he went into her office, I left the office.
So when I say I leave the
I don't remember exactly when Eric came up.
When Mr. Herschmann left, did Ms. Trump go with him or did he leave on
When you say a lot, what does that mean?
Why was he up there so many times?
But given your proximity to the office, could you at least hear the general
But this was after Ms. Trump had come back from visiting the Oval Office the
Eric was up there a lot that day.
I wasn't a part of the conversations.
tenor of the conversations and what was being discussed?
I took it as a cue to leave my desk area.
We have, in the course of the investigation, learned that Mr. Herschmann
and possibly others within the White House, asked Ms. Trump to weigh in with her father
about what to say about the violence at the Capitol.
was the tenor of the discussions Mr. Herschmann was having or others with Ms. Trump
Did you become aware that that
that day, to get her to speak to her father?
I heard about that after January 6th.
And how did you hear about that and from who?
Did you ever ask Ms. Trump about that?
As you were monitoring the President's tweets, social media during the day,
did you have a reaction to whether what he was saying was sufficient to meet the
moment of what was happening at the Capitol?
I mean, it was a pretty upsetting day.
So I'm not -- to be honest with you, it
was just a really upsetting day.
the other, other than just being, you know, upset about the situation.
And I don't really remember having a feeling one way or
Did you ever give advice to Ms. Trump that more needed to be done and
that she should speak to her father about that?
Were you discussing with her during that
afternoon of the 6th about what, if anything, more should be done in terms of the
What time do you remember leaving the White House that day?
that I think around 6:00 o'clock there was a curfew in the city and that a direction was
given at least to most staff to leave if they could.
I don't remember that specifically, but I do know we left around the 6:00
I just remember I know it was dark.
Have you ever spoken to anybody who's told you that they were with the
President at any point during January 6th while the attack was going on, and they told
you what he was saying or what they were doing during those meetings?
Let me stop to see if anybody who's on the call has any other questions.
I don't see anybody else raising their hand to speak.
I'll ask you at the end, Ms. Craddock.
Do you recall or do you know whether you
have any text messages, emails, or chats that would still be in your, you know, in your
phone or on your computer from the day of January 6th?
I'm sure there's something in my iCloud I have text messages from that day,
you know, letting people know when I'm coming home or going to work.
So using your personal phone, because those are the sorts of things you
could do personally, not on your government phone, right?
Yeah, and in terms of monitoring social media that day, was that on your
So I'll -- if -- would you be willing to look through and see if you have
anything related to just that day, messages or any chats or emails you would have sent
during the time of the attack?
And you can talk to with Mr. Benson about it and I can
Do you mind if I speak -- yeah.
But, otherwise, I think, Ms. Craddock, I told Mr. Benson we'd be efficient with your
I don't have any further questions.
I don't see that anybody else does.
So I want to say thank you again for taking the time to meet with you.
And, Dan, you let me know when you'd like to start our next appointment.
have to click a different link but happy to get going as soon as you're ready.
Probably I'm guessing about 10 minutes or so.
Should I email you when we're ready?
You'll send me the new link?
I'll log in and be ready to go when you're ready.
It's in the email I sent yesterday.
[Whereupon, at 2:45 p.m., the interview was concluded.]
I have read the foregoing _ _ pages, which contain the correct transcript of the
answers made by me to the questions therein recorded.
